Browse the source code of netbsd/external/bsd/libpcap/dist/sf-pcap.c

5 * The Regents of the University of California. All rights reserved.
6 *
7 * Redistribution and use in source and binary forms, with or without
8 * modification, are permitted provided that: (1) source code distributions
9 * retain the above copyright notice and this paragraph in its entirety, (2)
10 * distributions including binary code include the above copyright notice and
11 * this paragraph in its entirety in the documentation or other materials
12 * provided with the distribution, and (3) all advertising materials mentioning
13 * features or use of this software display the following acknowledgement:
14 * ``This product includes software developed by the University of California,
15 * Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory and its contributors.'' Neither the name of
16 * the University nor the names of its contributors may be used to endorse
17 * or promote products derived from this software without specific prior
18 * written permission.
19 * THIS SOFTWARE IS PROVIDED ``AS IS'' AND WITHOUT ANY EXPRESS OR IMPLIED
20 * WARRANTIES, INCLUDING, WITHOUT LIMITATION, THE IMPLIED WARRANTIES OF
21 * MERCHANTABILITY AND FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.
22 *
23 * sf-pcap.c - libpcap-file-format-specific code from savefile.c
24 * Extraction/creation by Jeffrey Mogul, DECWRL
25 * Modified by Steve McCanne, LBL.
26 *
27 * Used to save the received packet headers, after filtering, to
28 * a file, and then read them later.
29 * The first record in the file contains saved values for the machine
30 * dependent values so we can print the dump file on any architecture.
31 */
32
33#include <sys/cdefs.h>
34__RCSID("$NetBSD: sf-pcap.c,v 1.8 2018/09/03 15:26:43 christos Exp $");
35

62/*
63 * Setting O_BINARY on DOS/Windows is a bit tricky
64 */
65#if defined(_WIN32)
66 #define SET_BINMODE(f) _setmode(_fileno(f), _O_BINARY)
67#elif defined(MSDOS)
68 #if defined(__HIGHC__)
69 #define SET_BINMODE(f) setmode(f, O_BINARY)
70 #else
71 #define SET_BINMODE(f) setmode(fileno(f), O_BINARY)
72 #endif
73#endif
74
75/*
76 * Standard libpcap format.
77 */
78#define TCPDUMP_MAGIC 0xa1b2c3d4
79
80/*
81 * Alexey Kuznetzov's modified libpcap format.
82 */
83#define KUZNETZOV_TCPDUMP_MAGIC 0xa1b2cd34
84
85/*
86 * Reserved for Francisco Mesquita <francisco.mesquita@radiomovel.pt>
87 * for another modified format.
88 */
89#define FMESQUITA_TCPDUMP_MAGIC 0xa1b234cd
90
91/*
92 * Navtel Communcations' format, with nanosecond timestamps,
93 * as per a request from Dumas Hwang <dumas.hwang@navtelcom.com>.
94 */
95#define NAVTEL_TCPDUMP_MAGIC 0xa12b3c4d
96
97/*
98 * Normal libpcap format, except for seconds/nanoseconds timestamps,
99 * as per a request by Ulf Lamping <ulf.lamping@web.de>
100 */
101#define NSEC_TCPDUMP_MAGIC 0xa1b23c4d
102
103/*
104 * Mechanism for storing information about a capture in the upper
105 * 6 bits of a linktype value in a capture file.
106 *
107 * LT_LINKTYPE_EXT(x) extracts the additional information.
108 *
109 * The rest of the bits are for a value describing the link-layer
110 * value. LT_LINKTYPE(x) extracts that value.
111 */
112#define LT_LINKTYPE(x) ((x) & 0x03FFFFFF)
113#define LT_LINKTYPE_EXT(x) ((x) & 0xFC000000)
114
115static int pcap_next_packet(pcap_t *p, struct pcap_pkthdr *hdr, u_char **datap);
116
117/*
118 * Private data for reading pcap savefiles.
119 */
120typedef enum {
121 NOT_SWAPPED,
122 SWAPPED,
123 MAYBE_SWAPPED
124} swapped_type_t;
125
126typedef enum {
127 PASS_THROUGH,
128 SCALE_UP,
129 SCALE_DOWN
130} tstamp_scale_type_t;
131
132struct pcap_sf {
133 size_t hdrsize;
134 swapped_type_t lengths_swapped;
135 tstamp_scale_type_t scale_type;
136};
137
138/*
139 * Check whether this is a pcap savefile and, if it is, extract the
140 * relevant information from the header.
141 */
142pcap_t *
143pcap_check_header(bpf_u_int32 magic, FILE *fp, u_int precision, char *errbuf,
144 int *err)
145{
146 struct pcap_file_header hdr;
147 size_t amt_read;
148 pcap_t *p;
149 int swapped = 0;
150 struct pcap_sf *ps;
151
152 /*
153 * Assume no read errors.
154 */
155 *err = 0;
156
157 /*
158 * Check whether the first 4 bytes of the file are the magic
159 * number for a pcap savefile, or for a byte-swapped pcap
160 * savefile.
161 */
162 if (magic != TCPDUMP_MAGIC && magic != KUZNETZOV_TCPDUMP_MAGIC &&
163 magic != NSEC_TCPDUMP_MAGIC) {
164 magic = SWAPLONG(magic);
165 if (magic != TCPDUMP_MAGIC && magic != KUZNETZOV_TCPDUMP_MAGIC &&
166 magic != NSEC_TCPDUMP_MAGIC)
167 return (NULL); /* nope */
168 swapped = 1;
169 }
170
171 /*
172 * They are. Put the magic number in the header, and read
173 * the rest of the header.
174 */
175 hdr.magic = magic;
176 amt_read = fread(((char *)&hdr) + sizeof hdr.magic, 1,
177 sizeof(hdr) - sizeof(hdr.magic), fp);
178 if (amt_read != sizeof(hdr) - sizeof(hdr.magic)) {
179 if (ferror(fp)) {
180 pcap_fmt_errmsg_for_errno(errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
181 errno, "error reading dump file");
182 } else {
183 pcap_snprintf(errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
184 "truncated dump file; tried to read %lu file header bytes, only got %lu",
185 (unsigned long)sizeof(hdr),
186 (unsigned long)amt_read);
187 }
188 *err = 1;
189 return (NULL);
190 }
191
192 /*
193 * If it's a byte-swapped capture file, byte-swap the header.
194 */
195 if (swapped) {
196 hdr.version_major = SWAPSHORT(hdr.version_major);
197 hdr.version_minor = SWAPSHORT(hdr.version_minor);
198 hdr.thiszone = SWAPLONG(hdr.thiszone);
199 hdr.sigfigs = SWAPLONG(hdr.sigfigs);
200 hdr.snaplen = SWAPLONG(hdr.snaplen);
201 hdr.linktype = SWAPLONG(hdr.linktype);
202 }
203
204 if (hdr.version_major < PCAP_VERSION_MAJOR) {
205 pcap_snprintf(errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
206 "archaic pcap savefile format");
207 *err = 1;
208 return (NULL);
209 }
210
211 /*
212 * currently only versions 2.[0-4] are supported with
213 * the exception of 543.0 for DG/UX tcpdump.
214 */
215 if (! ((hdr.version_major == PCAP_VERSION_MAJOR &&
216 hdr.version_minor <= PCAP_VERSION_MINOR) ||
217 (hdr.version_major == 543 &&
218 hdr.version_minor == 0))) {
219 pcap_snprintf(errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
220 "unsupported pcap savefile version %u.%u",
221 hdr.version_major, hdr.version_minor);
222 *err = 1;
223 return NULL;
224 }
225
226 /*
227 * OK, this is a good pcap file.
228 * Allocate a pcap_t for it.
229 */
230 p = pcap_open_offline_common(errbuf, sizeof (struct pcap_sf));
231 if (p == NULL) {
232 /* Allocation failed. */
233 *err = 1;
234 return (NULL);
235 }
236 p->swapped = swapped;
237 p->version_major = hdr.version_major;
238 p->version_minor = hdr.version_minor;
239 p->tzoff = hdr.thiszone;
240 p->snapshot = hdr.snaplen;
241 if (p->snapshot <= 0) {
242 /*
243 * Bogus snapshot length; use the maximum for this
244 * link-layer type as a fallback.
245 *
246 * XXX - the only reason why snapshot is signed is
247 * that pcap_snapshot() returns an int, not an
248 * unsigned int.
249 */
250 p->snapshot = max_snaplen_for_dlt(hdr.linktype);
251 }
252 p->linktype = linktype_to_dlt(LT_LINKTYPE(hdr.linktype));
253 p->linktype_ext = LT_LINKTYPE_EXT(hdr.linktype);
254
255 p->next_packet_op = pcap_next_packet;
256
257 ps = p->priv;
258
259 p->opt.tstamp_precision = precision;
260
261 /*
262 * Will we need to scale the timestamps to match what the
263 * user wants?
264 */
265 switch (precision) {
266
267 case PCAP_TSTAMP_PRECISION_MICRO:
268 if (magic == NSEC_TCPDUMP_MAGIC) {
269 /*
270 * The file has nanoseconds, the user
271 * wants microseconds; scale the
272 * precision down.
273 */
274 ps->scale_type = SCALE_DOWN;
275 } else {
276 /*
277 * The file has microseconds, the
278 * user wants microseconds; nothing to do.
279 */
280 ps->scale_type = PASS_THROUGH;
281 }
282 break;
283
284 case PCAP_TSTAMP_PRECISION_NANO:
285 if (magic == NSEC_TCPDUMP_MAGIC) {
286 /*
287 * The file has nanoseconds, the
288 * user wants nanoseconds; nothing to do.
289 */
290 ps->scale_type = PASS_THROUGH;
291 } else {
292 /*
293 * The file has microoseconds, the user
294 * wants nanoseconds; scale the
295 * precision up.
296 */
297 ps->scale_type = SCALE_UP;
298 }
299 break;
300
301 default:
302 pcap_snprintf(errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
303 "unknown time stamp resolution %u", precision);
304 free(p);
305 *err = 1;
306 return (NULL);
307 }
308
309 /*
310 * We interchanged the caplen and len fields at version 2.3,
311 * in order to match the bpf header layout. But unfortunately
312 * some files were written with version 2.3 in their headers
313 * but without the interchanged fields.
314 *
315 * In addition, DG/UX tcpdump writes out files with a version
316 * number of 543.0, and with the caplen and len fields in the
317 * pre-2.3 order.
318 */
319 switch (hdr.version_major) {
320
321 case 2:
322 if (hdr.version_minor < 3)
323 ps->lengths_swapped = SWAPPED;
324 else if (hdr.version_minor == 3)
325 ps->lengths_swapped = MAYBE_SWAPPED;
326 else
327 ps->lengths_swapped = NOT_SWAPPED;
328 break;
329
330 case 543:
331 ps->lengths_swapped = SWAPPED;
332 break;
333
334 default:
335 ps->lengths_swapped = NOT_SWAPPED;
336 break;
337 }
338
339 if (magic == KUZNETZOV_TCPDUMP_MAGIC) {
340 /*
341 * XXX - the patch that's in some versions of libpcap
342 * changes the packet header but not the magic number,
343 * and some other versions with this magic number have
344 * some extra debugging information in the packet header;
345 * we'd have to use some hacks^H^H^H^H^Hheuristics to
346 * detect those variants.
347 *
348 * Ethereal does that, but it does so by trying to read
349 * the first two packets of the file with each of the
350 * record header formats. That currently means it seeks
351 * backwards and retries the reads, which doesn't work
352 * on pipes. We want to be able to read from a pipe, so
353 * that strategy won't work; we'd have to buffer some
354 * data ourselves and read from that buffer in order to
355 * make that work.
356 */
357 ps->hdrsize = sizeof(struct pcap_sf_patched_pkthdr);
358
359 if (p->linktype == DLT_EN10MB) {
360 /*
361 * This capture might have been done in raw mode
362 * or cooked mode.
363 *
364 * If it was done in cooked mode, p->snapshot was
365 * passed to recvfrom() as the buffer size, meaning
366 * that the most packet data that would be copied
367 * would be p->snapshot. However, a faked Ethernet
368 * header would then have been added to it, so the
369 * most data that would be in a packet in the file
370 * would be p->snapshot + 14.
371 *
372 * We can't easily tell whether the capture was done
373 * in raw mode or cooked mode, so we'll assume it was
374 * cooked mode, and add 14 to the snapshot length.
375 * That means that, for a raw capture, the snapshot
376 * length will be misleading if you use it to figure
377 * out why a capture doesn't have all the packet data,
378 * but there's not much we can do to avoid that.
379 */
380 p->snapshot += 14;
381 }
382 } else
383 ps->hdrsize = sizeof(struct pcap_sf_pkthdr);
384
385 /*
386 * Allocate a buffer for the packet data.
387 * Choose the minimum of the file's snapshot length and 2K bytes;
388 * that should be enough for most network packets - we'll grow it
389 * if necessary. That way, we don't allocate a huge chunk of
390 * memory just because there's a huge snapshot length, as the
391 * snapshot length might be larger than the size of the largest
392 * packet.
393 */
394 p->bufsize = p->snapshot;
395 if (p->bufsize > 2048)
396 p->bufsize = 2048;
397 p->buffer = malloc(p->bufsize);
398 if (p->buffer == NULL) {
399 pcap_snprintf(errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE, "out of memory");
400 free(p);
401 *err = 1;
402 return (NULL);
403 }
404
405 p->cleanup_op = sf_cleanup;
406
407 return (p);
408}
409
410/*
411 * Grow the packet buffer to the specified size.
412 */
413static int
414grow_buffer(pcap_t *p, u_int bufsize)
415{
416 void *bigger_buffer;
417
418 bigger_buffer = realloc(p->buffer, bufsize);
419 if (bigger_buffer == NULL) {
420 pcap_snprintf(p->errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE, "out of memory");
421 return (0);
422 }
423 p->buffer = bigger_buffer;
424 p->bufsize = bufsize;
425 return (1);
426}
427
428/*
429 * Read and return the next packet from the savefile. Return the header
430 * in hdr and a pointer to the contents in data. Return 0 on success, 1
431 * if there were no more packets, and -1 on an error.
432 */
433static int
434pcap_next_packet(pcap_t *p, struct pcap_pkthdr *hdr, u_char **data)
435{
436 struct pcap_sf *ps = p->priv;
437 struct pcap_sf_patched_pkthdr sf_hdr;
438 FILE *fp = p->rfile;
439 size_t amt_read;
440 bpf_u_int32 t;
441
442 /*
443 * Read the packet header; the structure we use as a buffer
444 * is the longer structure for files generated by the patched
445 * libpcap, but if the file has the magic number for an
446 * unpatched libpcap we only read as many bytes as the regular
447 * header has.
448 */
449 amt_read = fread(&sf_hdr, 1, ps->hdrsize, fp);
450 if (amt_read != ps->hdrsize) {
451 if (ferror(fp)) {
452 pcap_fmt_errmsg_for_errno(p->errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
453 errno, "error reading dump file");
454 return (-1);
455 } else {
456 if (amt_read != 0) {
457 pcap_snprintf(p->errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
458 "truncated dump file; tried to read %lu header bytes, only got %lu",
459 (unsigned long)ps->hdrsize,
460 (unsigned long)amt_read);
461 return (-1);
462 }
463 /* EOF */
464 return (1);
465 }
466 }
467
468 if (p->swapped) {
469 /* these were written in opposite byte order */
470 hdr->caplen = SWAPLONG(sf_hdr.caplen);
471 hdr->len = SWAPLONG(sf_hdr.len);
472 hdr->ts.tv_sec = SWAPLONG(sf_hdr.ts.tv_sec);
473 hdr->ts.tv_usec = SWAPLONG(sf_hdr.ts.tv_usec);
474 } else {
475 hdr->caplen = sf_hdr.caplen;
476 hdr->len = sf_hdr.len;
477 hdr->ts.tv_sec = sf_hdr.ts.tv_sec;
478 hdr->ts.tv_usec = sf_hdr.ts.tv_usec;
479 }
480
481 switch (ps->scale_type) {
482
483 case PASS_THROUGH:
484 /*
485 * Just pass the time stamp through.
486 */
487 break;
488
489 case SCALE_UP:
490 /*
491 * File has microseconds, user wants nanoseconds; convert
492 * it.
493 */
494 hdr->ts.tv_usec = hdr->ts.tv_usec * 1000;
495 break;
496
497 case SCALE_DOWN:
498 /*
499 * File has nanoseconds, user wants microseconds; convert
500 * it.
501 */
502 hdr->ts.tv_usec = hdr->ts.tv_usec / 1000;
503 break;
504 }
505
506 /* Swap the caplen and len fields, if necessary. */
507 switch (ps->lengths_swapped) {
508
509 case NOT_SWAPPED:
510 break;
511
512 case MAYBE_SWAPPED:
513 if (hdr->caplen <= hdr->len) {
514 /*
515 * The captured length is <= the actual length,
516 * so presumably they weren't swapped.
517 */
518 break;
519 }
520 /* FALLTHROUGH */
521
522 case SWAPPED:
523 t = hdr->caplen;
524 hdr->caplen = hdr->len;
525 hdr->len = t;
526 break;
527 }
528
529 /*
530 * Is the packet bigger than we consider sane?
531 */
532 if (hdr->caplen > max_snaplen_for_dlt(p->linktype)) {
533 /*
534 * Yes. This may be a damaged or fuzzed file.
535 *
536 * Is it bigger than the snapshot length?
537 * (We don't treat that as an error if it's not
538 * bigger than the maximum we consider sane; see
539 * below.)
540 */
541 if (hdr->caplen > (bpf_u_int32)p->snapshot) {
542 pcap_snprintf(p->errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
543 "invalid packet capture length %u, bigger than "
544 "snaplen of %d", hdr->caplen, p->snapshot);
545 } else {
546 pcap_snprintf(p->errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
547 "invalid packet capture length %u, bigger than "
548 "maximum of %u", hdr->caplen,
549 max_snaplen_for_dlt(p->linktype));
550 }
551 return (-1);
552 }
553
554 if (hdr->caplen > (bpf_u_int32)p->snapshot) {
555 /*
556 * The packet is bigger than the snapshot length
557 * for this file.
558 *
559 * This can happen due to Solaris 2.3 systems tripping
560 * over the BUFMOD problem and not setting the snapshot
561 * length correctly in the savefile header.
562 *
563 * libpcap 0.4 and later on Solaris 2.3 should set the
564 * snapshot length correctly in the pcap file header,
565 * even though they don't set a snapshot length in bufmod
566 * (the buggy bufmod chops off the *beginning* of the
567 * packet if a snapshot length is specified); they should
568 * also reduce the captured length, as supplied to the
569 * per-packet callback, to the snapshot length if it's
570 * greater than the snapshot length, so the code using
571 * libpcap should see the packet cut off at the snapshot
572 * length, even though the full packet is copied up to
573 * userland.
574 *
575 * However, perhaps some versions of libpcap failed to
576 * set the snapshot length currectly in the file header
577 * or the per-packet header, or perhaps this is a
578 * corrupted safefile or a savefile built/modified by a
579 * fuzz tester, so we check anyway. We grow the buffer
580 * to be big enough for the snapshot length, read up
581 * to the snapshot length, discard the rest of the
582 * packet, and report the snapshot length as the captured
583 * length; we don't want to hand our caller a packet
584 * bigger than the snapshot length, because they might
585 * be assuming they'll never be handed such a packet,
586 * and might copy the packet into a snapshot-length-
587 * sized buffer, assuming it'll fit.
588 */
589 size_t bytes_to_discard;
590 size_t bytes_to_read, bytes_read;
591 char discard_buf[4096];
592
593 if (hdr->caplen > p->bufsize) {
594 /*
595 * Grow the buffer to the snapshot length.
596 */
597 if (!grow_buffer(p, p->snapshot))
598 return (-1);
599 }
600
601 /*
602 * Read the first p->snapshot bytes into the buffer.
603 */
604 amt_read = fread(p->buffer, 1, p->snapshot, fp);
605 if (amt_read != (bpf_u_int32)p->snapshot) {
606 if (ferror(fp)) {
607 pcap_fmt_errmsg_for_errno(p->errbuf,
608 PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE, errno,
609 "error reading dump file");
610 } else {
611 /*
612 * Yes, this uses hdr->caplen; technically,
613 * it's true, because we would try to read
614 * and discard the rest of those bytes, and
615 * that would fail because we got EOF before
616 * the read finished.
617 */
618 pcap_snprintf(p->errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
619 "truncated dump file; tried to read %u captured bytes, only got %lu",
620 p->snapshot, (unsigned long)amt_read);
621 }
622 return (-1);
623 }
624
625 /*
626 * Now read and discard what's left.
627 */
628 bytes_to_discard = hdr->caplen - p->snapshot;
629 bytes_read = amt_read;
630 while (bytes_to_discard != 0) {
631 bytes_to_read = bytes_to_discard;
632 if (bytes_to_read > sizeof (discard_buf))
633 bytes_to_read = sizeof (discard_buf);
634 amt_read = fread(discard_buf, 1, bytes_to_read, fp);
635 bytes_read += amt_read;
636 if (amt_read != bytes_to_read) {
637 if (ferror(fp)) {
638 pcap_fmt_errmsg_for_errno(p->errbuf,
639 PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE, errno,
640 "error reading dump file");
641 } else {
642 pcap_snprintf(p->errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
643 "truncated dump file; tried to read %u captured bytes, only got %lu",
644 hdr->caplen, (unsigned long)bytes_read);
645 }
646 return (-1);
647 }
648 bytes_to_discard -= amt_read;
649 }
650
651 /*
652 * Adjust caplen accordingly, so we don't get confused later
653 * as to how many bytes we have to play with.
654 */
655 hdr->caplen = p->snapshot;
656 } else {
657 if (hdr->caplen > p->bufsize) {
658 /*
659 * Grow the buffer to the next power of 2, or
660 * the snaplen, whichever is lower.
661 */
662 u_int new_bufsize;
663
664 new_bufsize = hdr->caplen;
665 /*
666 * http://graphics.stanford.edu/~seander/bithacks.html#RoundUpPowerOf2
667 */
668 new_bufsize--;
669 new_bufsize |= new_bufsize >> 1;
670 new_bufsize |= new_bufsize >> 2;
671 new_bufsize |= new_bufsize >> 4;
672 new_bufsize |= new_bufsize >> 8;
673 new_bufsize |= new_bufsize >> 16;
674 new_bufsize++;
675
676 if (new_bufsize > (u_int)p->snapshot)
677 new_bufsize = p->snapshot;
678
679 if (!grow_buffer(p, new_bufsize))
680 return (-1);
681 }
682
683 /* read the packet itself */
684 amt_read = fread(p->buffer, 1, hdr->caplen, fp);
685 if (amt_read != hdr->caplen) {
686 if (ferror(fp)) {
687 pcap_fmt_errmsg_for_errno(p->errbuf,
688 PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE, errno,
689 "error reading dump file");
690 } else {
691 pcap_snprintf(p->errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
692 "truncated dump file; tried to read %u captured bytes, only got %lu",
693 hdr->caplen, (unsigned long)amt_read);
694 }
695 return (-1);
696 }
697 }
698 *data = p->buffer;
699
700 if (p->swapped)
701 swap_pseudo_headers(p->linktype, hdr, *data);
702
703 return (0);
704}
705
706static int
707sf_write_header(pcap_t *p, FILE *fp, int linktype, int thiszone, int snaplen)
708{
709 struct pcap_file_header hdr;
710
711 hdr.magic = p->opt.tstamp_precision == PCAP_TSTAMP_PRECISION_NANO ? NSEC_TCPDUMP_MAGIC : TCPDUMP_MAGIC;
712 hdr.version_major = PCAP_VERSION_MAJOR;
713 hdr.version_minor = PCAP_VERSION_MINOR;
714
715 hdr.thiszone = thiszone;
716 hdr.snaplen = snaplen;
717 hdr.sigfigs = 0;
718 hdr.linktype = linktype;
719
720 if (fwrite((char *)&hdr, sizeof(hdr), 1, fp) != 1)
721 return (-1);
722
723 return (0);
724}
725
726/*
727 * Output a packet to the initialized dump file.
728 */
729void
730pcap_dump(u_char *user, const struct pcap_pkthdr *h, const u_char *sp)
731{
732 register FILE *f;
733 struct pcap_sf_pkthdr sf_hdr;
734
735 f = (FILE *)user;
736 sf_hdr.ts.tv_sec = h->ts.tv_sec;
737 sf_hdr.ts.tv_usec = h->ts.tv_usec;
738 sf_hdr.caplen = h->caplen;
739 sf_hdr.len = h->len;
740 /* XXX we should check the return status */
741 (void)fwrite(&sf_hdr, sizeof(sf_hdr), 1, f);
742 (void)fwrite(sp, h->caplen, 1, f);
743}
744
745static pcap_dumper_t *
746pcap_setup_dump(pcap_t *p, int linktype, FILE *f, const char *fname)
747{
748
749#if defined(_WIN32) || defined(MSDOS)
750 /*
751 * If we're writing to the standard output, put it in binary
752 * mode, as savefiles are binary files.
753 *
754 * Otherwise, we turn off buffering.
755 * XXX - why? And why not on the standard output?
756 */
757 if (f == stdout)
758 SET_BINMODE(f);
759 else
760 setvbuf(f, NULL, _IONBF, 0);
761#endif
762 if (sf_write_header(p, f, linktype, p->tzoff, p->snapshot) == -1) {
763 pcap_fmt_errmsg_for_errno(p->errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
764 errno, "Can't write to %s", fname);
765 if (f != stdout)
766 (void)fclose(f);
767 return (NULL);
768 }
769 return ((pcap_dumper_t *)f);
770}
771
772/*
773 * Initialize so that sf_write() will output to the file named 'fname'.
774 */
775pcap_dumper_t *
776pcap_dump_open(pcap_t *p, const char *fname)
777{
778 FILE *f;
779 int linktype;
780
781 /*
782 * If this pcap_t hasn't been activated, it doesn't have a
783 * link-layer type, so we can't use it.
784 */
785 if (!p->activated) {
786 pcap_snprintf(p->errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
787 "%s: not-yet-activated pcap_t passed to pcap_dump_open",
788 fname);
789 return (NULL);
790 }
791 linktype = dlt_to_linktype(p->linktype);
792 if (linktype == -1) {
793 pcap_snprintf(p->errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
794 "%s: link-layer type %d isn't supported in savefiles",
795 fname, p->linktype);
796 return (NULL);
797 }
798 linktype |= p->linktype_ext;
799
800 if (fname == NULL) {
801 pcap_snprintf(p->errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
802 "A null pointer was supplied as the file name");
803 return NULL;
804 }
805 if (fname[0] == '-' && fname[1] == '\0') {
806 f = stdout;
807 fname = "standard output";
808 } else {
809 /*
810 * "b" is supported as of C90, so *all* UN*Xes should
811 * support it, even though it does nothing. It's
812 * required on Windows, as the file is a binary file
813 * and must be written in binary mode.
814 */
815 f = fopen(fname, "wb");
816 if (f == NULL) {
817 pcap_fmt_errmsg_for_errno(p->errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
818 errno, "%s", fname);
819 return (NULL);
820 }
821 }
822 return (pcap_setup_dump(p, linktype, f, fname));
823}
824
825/*
826 * Initialize so that sf_write() will output to the given stream.
827 */
828pcap_dumper_t *
829pcap_dump_fopen(pcap_t *p, FILE *f)
830{
831 int linktype;
832
833 linktype = dlt_to_linktype(p->linktype);
834 if (linktype == -1) {
835 pcap_snprintf(p->errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
836 "stream: link-layer type %d isn't supported in savefiles",
837 p->linktype);
838 return (NULL);
839 }
840 linktype |= p->linktype_ext;
841
842 return (pcap_setup_dump(p, linktype, f, "stream"));
843}
844
845pcap_dumper_t *
846pcap_dump_open_append(pcap_t *p, const char *fname)
847{
848 FILE *f;
849 int linktype;
850 size_t amt_read;
851 struct pcap_file_header ph;
852
853 linktype = dlt_to_linktype(p->linktype);
854 if (linktype == -1) {
855 pcap_snprintf(p->errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
856 "%s: link-layer type %d isn't supported in savefiles",
857 fname, linktype);
858 return (NULL);
859 }
860
861 if (fname == NULL) {
862 pcap_snprintf(p->errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
863 "A null pointer was supplied as the file name");
864 return NULL;
865 }
866 if (fname[0] == '-' && fname[1] == '\0')
867 return (pcap_setup_dump(p, linktype, stdout, "standard output"));
868
869 /*
870 * "b" is supported as of C90, so *all* UN*Xes should support it,
871 * even though it does nothing. It's required on Windows, as the
872 * file is a binary file and must be read in binary mode.
873 */
874 f = fopen(fname, "rb+");
875 if (f == NULL) {
876 pcap_fmt_errmsg_for_errno(p->errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
877 errno, "%s", fname);
878 return (NULL);
879 }
880
881 /*
882 * Try to read a pcap header.
883 */
884 amt_read = fread(&ph, 1, sizeof (ph), f);
885 if (amt_read != sizeof (ph)) {
886 if (ferror(f)) {
887 pcap_fmt_errmsg_for_errno(p->errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
888 errno, "%s", fname);
889 fclose(f);
890 return (NULL);
891 } else if (feof(f) && amt_read > 0) {
892 pcap_snprintf(p->errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
893 "%s: truncated pcap file header", fname);
894 fclose(f);
895 return (NULL);
896 }
897 }
898
899#if defined(_WIN32) || defined(MSDOS)
900 /*
901 * We turn off buffering.
902 * XXX - why? And why not on the standard output?
903 */
904 setvbuf(f, NULL, _IONBF, 0);
905#endif
906
907 /*
908 * If a header is already present and:
909 *
910 * it's not for a pcap file of the appropriate resolution
911 * and the right byte order for this machine;
912 *
913 * the link-layer header types don't match;
914 *
915 * the snapshot lengths don't match;
916 *
917 * return an error.
918 */
919 if (amt_read > 0) {
920 /*
921 * A header is already present.
922 * Do the checks.
923 */
924 switch (ph.magic) {
925
926 case TCPDUMP_MAGIC:
927 if (p->opt.tstamp_precision != PCAP_TSTAMP_PRECISION_MICRO) {
928 pcap_snprintf(p->errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
929 "%s: different time stamp precision, cannot append to file", fname);
930 fclose(f);
931 return (NULL);
932 }
933 break;
934
935 case NSEC_TCPDUMP_MAGIC:
936 if (p->opt.tstamp_precision != PCAP_TSTAMP_PRECISION_NANO) {
937 pcap_snprintf(p->errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
938 "%s: different time stamp precision, cannot append to file", fname);
939 fclose(f);
940 return (NULL);
941 }
942 break;
943
944 case SWAPLONG(TCPDUMP_MAGIC):
945 case SWAPLONG(NSEC_TCPDUMP_MAGIC):
946 pcap_snprintf(p->errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
947 "%s: different byte order, cannot append to file", fname);
948 fclose(f);
949 return (NULL);
950
951 case KUZNETZOV_TCPDUMP_MAGIC:
952 case SWAPLONG(KUZNETZOV_TCPDUMP_MAGIC):
953 case NAVTEL_TCPDUMP_MAGIC:
954 case SWAPLONG(NAVTEL_TCPDUMP_MAGIC):
955 pcap_snprintf(p->errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
956 "%s: not a pcap file to which we can append", fname);
957 fclose(f);
958 return (NULL);
959
960 default:
961 pcap_snprintf(p->errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
962 "%s: not a pcap file", fname);
963 fclose(f);
964 return (NULL);
965 }
966
967 /*
968 * Good version?
969 */
970 if (ph.version_major != PCAP_VERSION_MAJOR ||
971 ph.version_minor != PCAP_VERSION_MINOR) {
972 pcap_snprintf(p->errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
973 "%s: version is %u.%u, cannot append to file", fname,
974 ph.version_major, ph.version_minor);
975 fclose(f);
976 return (NULL);
977 }
978 if ((bpf_u_int32)linktype != ph.linktype) {
979 pcap_snprintf(p->errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
980 "%s: different linktype, cannot append to file", fname);
981 fclose(f);
982 return (NULL);
983 }
984 if ((bpf_u_int32)p->snapshot != ph.snaplen) {
985 pcap_snprintf(p->errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
986 "%s: different snaplen, cannot append to file", fname);
987 fclose(f);
988 return (NULL);
989 }
990 } else {
991 /*
992 * A header isn't present; attempt to write it.
993 */
994 if (sf_write_header(p, f, linktype, p->tzoff, p->snapshot) == -1) {
995 pcap_fmt_errmsg_for_errno(p->errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
996 errno, "Can't write to %s", fname);
997 (void)fclose(f);
998 return (NULL);
999 }
1000 }
1001
1002 /*
1003 * Start writing at the end of the file.
1004 */
1005 if (fseek(f, 0, SEEK_END) == -1) {
1006 pcap_fmt_errmsg_for_errno(p->errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
1007 errno, "Can't seek to end of %s", fname);
1008 (void)fclose(f);
1009 return (NULL);
1010 }
1011 return ((pcap_dumper_t *)f);
1012}
1013
1014FILE *
1015pcap_dump_file(pcap_dumper_t *p)
1016{
1017 return ((FILE *)p);
1018}
1019
1020long
1021pcap_dump_ftell(pcap_dumper_t *p)
1022{
1023 return (ftell((FILE *)p));
1024}
1025
1026#if defined(HAVE_FSEEKO)
1027/*
1028 * We have fseeko(), so we have ftello().
1029 * If we have large file support (files larger than 2^31-1 bytes),
1030 * ftello() will give us a current file position with more than 32
1031 * bits.
1032 */
1033int64_t
1034pcap_dump_ftell64(pcap_dumper_t *p)
1035{
1036 return (ftello((FILE *)p));
1037}
1038#elif defined(_MSC_VER)
1039/*
1040 * We have Visual Studio; we support only 2005 and later, so we have
1041 * _ftelli64().
1042 */
1043int64_t
1044pcap_dump_ftell64(pcap_dumper_t *p)
1045{
1046 return (_ftelli64((FILE *)p));
1047}
1048#else
1049/*
1050 * We don't have ftello() or _ftelli64(), so fall back on ftell().
1051 * Either long is 64 bits, in which case ftell() should suffice,
1052 * or this is probably an older 32-bit UN*X without large file
1053 * support, which means you'll probably get errors trying to
1054 * write files > 2^31-1, so it won't matter anyway.
1055 *
1056 * XXX - what about MinGW?
1057 */
1058int64_t
1059pcap_dump_ftell64(pcap_dumper_t *p)
1060{
1061 return (ftell((FILE *)p));
1062}
1063#endif
1064
1065int
1066pcap_dump_flush(pcap_dumper_t *p)
1067{
1068
1069 if (fflush((FILE *)p) == EOF)
1070 return (-1);
1071 else
1072 return (0);
1073}
1074
1075void
1076pcap_dump_close(pcap_dumper_t *p)
1077{
1078
1079#ifdef notyet
1080 if (ferror((FILE *)p))
1081 return-an-error;
1082 /* XXX should check return from fclose() too */
1083#endif
1084 (void)fclose((FILE *)p);
1085}
